messages.content: What’s the Islamic phrase that says I only complain to god

The Islamic phrase you're referring to is:

**"Innamā ashkū bathhī wa ḥuznī ilā Allāh"**  
**(إِنَّمَا أَشْكُو بَثِّي وَحُزْنِي إِلَى ٱللَّهِ)**

It translates to:  
**"I only complain of my suffering and my grief to Allah."**

This is a quote from Prophet Ya'qub (Jacob, peace be upon him) in the Qur’an, **Surah Yusuf (12:86)**. He says this in a moment of deep sorrow, showing his reliance on God alone in times of distress. It’s often used to express spiritual surrender and heartfelt connection in hardship.
Any others I thought there was one that said only to god

Yes, you're right—there are a few phrases and sentiments in Islamic tradition that express the idea of turning only to God, especially in times of hardship. Here are a few relevant ones:

---

### 1. **"Hasbiyallāhu wa ni‘ma al-wakīl"**  
**(حَسْبِيَ اللَّهُ وَنِعْمَ الْوَكِيلُ)**  
**"Allah is sufficient for me, and He is the best disposer of affairs."**

This reflects full reliance on God alone, often said when facing difficulty or injustice.

---

### 2. **"Wa ilā Allāhi al-maṣīr"**  
**(وَإِلَى ٱللَّهِ ٱلْمَصِيرُ)**  
**"And to Allah is the final return."**

Used to express that everything ultimately goes back to God—including our concerns, actions, and fate.

---

### 3. **"Lā ḥawla wa lā quwwata illā billāh"**  
**(لَا حَوْلَ وَلَا قُوَّةَ إِلَّا بِاللَّهِ)**  
**"There is no power and no strength except with Allah."**

This is a powerful expression of humility and total dependence on God.

---

### 4. **"Innamā ashkū baththī wa ḥuznī ilā Allāh"** (as mentioned above)  
From Surah Yusuf 12:86, meaning:  
**"I only complain of my suffering and grief to Allah."**

---

If you’re thinking of a more poetic or Sufi phrase that translates to “I complain only to God” or “Only to God do I speak of what is in my heart,” it may not be a direct Qur’anic verse but rather a paraphrase or interpretation of the above concepts—common in Islamic poetry, du’a, or reflection.

Would you like the phrase written in calligraphic Arabic or transliterated for pronunciation?
